title: 2  Introducing graphics transformations
text:
2.1 Introduction
There are three basic transformations that are essential to world of computer graphichs, which are:

Scaling.
Translation.
Rotation.


library(ggplot2)
triangle <- data.frame(
  x = c(-1, 1, 0),
  y = c(0, 0, 1)
)

ggplot(triangle) +
  geom_polygon(
    aes(x = x, y = y),
    fill = "#222222"
  )

title: 2  Introducing graphics transformations
text:
In computer graphics, our main objective is (usually) to display multiple shapes (or objects) in the computer screen. But, in order to do that, we might need to change some attributes of these shapes (or objects).
For example, we might need to move these shapes to different locations in the screen, or to scale these shapes to a different size, or maybe, to rotate them into a different angle. To do this, we apply a transformation to each shape (or object) that we want to display in the screen.
There are three basic transformations that are essential to world of computer graphics, which are:

Scaling.
Translation.
Rotation.

Each of these three basic transformations use simple math operations over the coordinates of each vertice that compose your shape/object to achieve a specific visual effect/transformation. In essence:

Scaling is used to scale your object into a different size (i.e. to raise/shrink the size of your object).
Translation is used to move your object to a different position in the coordinate system.
Rotation is used to rotate your object to a different angle.


library(ggplot2)
triangle <- data.frame(
  x = c(-1, 1, 0),
  y = c(0, 0, 2)
)

canvas <- ggplot() +
  theme_minimal() +
  lims(y = c(-5, 5), x = c(-5, 5)) +
  geom_vline(aes(xintercept = 0), color = "#222222") +
  geom_hline(aes(yintercept = 0), color = "#222222")

canvas +
  geom_polygon(
    aes(x = x, y = y),
    fill = "#5384d4",
    data= triangle
  )
